text:
Photo: Mayra Beltran, Houston Chronicle Image 5. of 17 | To sauce or not to sauce 
Sauce is integral to Kansas City barbecue. This is pitmaster Keith Rogers basteing ribs at Fiorella's Jack Stack Barbecue in Kansas City. Sauce is integral to Kansas City barbecue. This is pitmaster Keith... Photo: Bob Fila Image 6. of 17 | 
No signs of sauce on these ribs from Killen's Texas Barbecue . Houston pitmasters generally serve their sauce on the side. No signs of sauce on these ribs from Killen's Texas Barbecue .... Photo: Jon Shapley, Houston Chronicle Image 7. of 17 | Good vs. great 
Celebrity chef Anthony Bourdain famously called Oklahoma Joe's Kansas City Bar-B-Que "one of the 13 places to eat before you die." To end some confusion, the restaurant changed its name last year to Joe's Kansas City Bar-B-Que Celebrity chef Anthony Bourdain famously called Oklahoma Joe's... More recently, the Food Network named Ronnie Killen 's Pearland restaurant the No. 2 barbecue in the country. It cited specifically the brisket at Killen's Barbecue . (In the same show, the aforementioned Joe's Kansas City was No. 5.) More recently, the Food Network named Ronnie Killen 's Pearland... Photo: Jon Shapley, Houston Chronicle Image 9. of 17 | Mascots

This is Goode Co. 's awesome armadillo. Image 11. of 17 | History lessons 
Kansas City's barbecue history is said to have begun with Henry Perry , who served his smoked meats beginning in 1908. Perry worked with Charlie Bryant , who ran the business after its founder died. Bryant would later turn over the bbq joint to his brother Arthur. It was Arthur who made Kansas City barbecue famous. Kansas City's barbecue history is said to have begun with Henry... Pizzitola's cooks meats in an old-fashioned open brick pit. Pizzitola's pits are the same one used by John and Lela Davis in the 1930s.
